poem:
Title: The Rustling of the Saltire

Disillusion in Airdie and Shotts,
the silent chant of their hearts,
Labour reds wilt, campaigners caught.
In saltires and scrawled graffiti arts,
echoes of abandonment fraught.
Not jumped ship, dear Labour,
You, the heartland, forgot.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The SNP’s woes are a boost for Starmer. But he’s not promising the change Scotland wants | Dani Garavelli In May 2015, as part of my newspaper’s general election coverage, I went out with Labour campaigners as they canvassed in one of the party’s heartlands: Airdrie and Shotts. The campaigners were in denial, but the signs of collapse were everywhere: in the many saltires, the “red Tories” graffiti, and the “I didn’t leave Labour, Labour". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
